trial_identification.studytitle: The Central Sydney Tai Chi trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The Central Sydney Tai Chi trial: A randomised controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of Tai Chi in reducing the risk of falling in older people

interventions.interventions: A 16-week introductory, community-based Tai Chi programme for older people consisting of 1-hour classes held weekly
interventions.comparator: Control group participants were placed on a waiting list to do tai chi after the intervention classes had finished. Control group participants were requested to not do any other tai chi during the study period

primaryOutcome.timepoint: At the end of the study period at 6-months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Number of falls; time to fall
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the end of the study period at 6-months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Balance while standing, leaning and stepping
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the end of the intervention at 4-months.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Living in the community; no experience with Tai Chi for at least the previous 12 months.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Degenerative neurological condition( such as Parkinsons or Alzheimers disease); a severely debilitating stroke; dementia; severe arthritis; marked vision impairment; or if unable to walk across a room unaided.

trial_design.concealment: Concealed randomised sequence held by chief investigator with allocation only after completion of baseline measures
trial_design.sequence: Random number table was used to generate the sequence using random permuted blocks.
trial_design.designfeatures: Waiting-list controlled group was offered the Tai Chi programme at the end of the study period

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study looks at whether a 16-week introductory Tai Chi programme, based in the community, will reduce the number of falls in older people and also whether Tai Chi will improve their balance
